title: What's the best digital piano for an absolute beginner looking to learn piano? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think that's a bit expensive for a beginner, but if you can afford it, go for it. You can't go wrong with that as long as you keep it up. Personally, I'd say go try out some digital pianos at a store and see cheaper options for yourself, but if you're a complete beginner, you probably don't know what "feels right."  So do this: Go to a piano store, sit on some Steinways, Yamahas, and Estonias and press down on some keys. Press down softly. Press down sharp and hard. Press down lightly and slowly. Press down normally. Rest your fingers on the keys. Notice how different and dynamic each note sounds according to how you press, strike, or caress each of the keys. Notice how the keys feel. It will take some effort--but a comfortable, natural effort--to make those keys depress and play a note. Feel how the keys come back up upon your fingers as you let it rise. It should feel smooth. This is all due to the action of the piano. This is how a real piano feels and sounds. The keys are "weighted." Your digital piano needs to mimic this as best as possible.  Now look down at your feet. You'll see three pedals. Press the pedal to the very right and press a key. Note that the sound is sustained. This is the sustain pedal. Now let go of that pedal and press the pedal to the very left and press a key. Notice that the sound of the note is duller and soft. This is the soft pedal. Your digital piano needs these as well.   Now go try some digital pianos. First cross out all the pianos that do not have 88 keys. Then start trying them out and see which of them feel and sound like the real pianos you played earlier. You'll notice that the cheap ones won't vary in sound no matter how hard or soft you strike the keys. You'll also notice that the keys depress almost instantly as you rest your fingers. These are the terrible ones. Don't bother with these. Next, you'll find a group of digital pianos with a bit of weight to them and a bit of variation to the sound of notes, but it feels almost cheap. The keys clunk down and rebound back up. They feel hollow. As you let the keys come back up upon your fingers, it doesn't quite feel right. Don't go for these as well. They're worth considering if the price is cheap, but try to avoid these. Next, you'll find a group that feels just the real thing. Go for these. Some brands may or may not last longer than others, but that will take years and years. Finally, check and see if there are pedals by your feet. Once you find a few that meet your criteria (1. 88 keys, 2. weighted keys, 3. soft and sustain pedal), compare prices and go buy it.  I hope this helps. Happy learning.

Yamaha P45B Digital Piano (Includes Knox bench, Knox double X stand, headphones, dust cover, sustain pedal and FastTrack Keyboard Method starter pack.) Summary of features: 88-keys, GHS weighted action on the keys, stereo sampling, USB port, sustain pedal. Pros The bundle comes with everything a beginner needs to get started right awayKeys are well-weighted and feel very real for a digital pianoCan handle serious beginners as they get into more complex piecesCons Bench and stand are relatively fragileSimple, no bells and whistlesJust 5 voicesThis piano is a beginner’s dream it’s sophisticated enough to keep using for years, especially in combination with 88 keys, a sustain pedal, and the 64-note polyphony, allowing for moderately dense passages, but comes with all the pieces for a beginner to get started, including a starter pack for learning the basics. Yamaha PSR-EW300 SA 76-Key Portable Keyboard (Includes stand and power supply.) Summary of features: 76 keys, 574 voices, 165 styles, and 154 preset songs, plus ability to add more with MIDI files. Pros Adjustable touch responseMany, many voicesIntuitive connection via USB with other devicesLesson modeCons Keys are not weightedLower polyphonyNot full sizeThe best part of a keyboard is the ability to play with voices and styles. The ability to apply preset and downloaded songs also helps beginners play full pieces as quickly as possible. Korg B1SP 88 Weighted Key Digital Piano (Includes stand, three-pedal board and Knox bench.) Summary of features: 88-keys, weighted hammer action on keys, build in stereo sound system, 3 pedals, 120 voices, AC output. Pros Feels like a stand-up pianoFull size (88 keys)3 pedalsGreat soundCons Not that loudOne output jack, no MIDI or no USBThe stand isn’t very stableThis digital piano looks like a real stand up piano and even feels like one when you’re playing it because of the 88 weighted hammer action on the keys. The sound produced can be quite similar too, because of the 120 voices that this piano includes. Yamaha P45 88-Key Weighted Action Digital Piano (Includes sustain pedal and power supply.) Summary of features: 88 keys, sustain pedal, 10 voices (and ability to combine 2 voices), weighted keys, USB port. Pros Full size (88 keys)Dual-mode for a combination of voicesExcellent weighted keysCons Mediocre touch sensibilityInconsistency in volume in a lower pitchKeys are noisyContrary to many of the Yamaha digital pianos targeted to beginners, that tend to have excellent touch sensibility but are not weighted, the Yamaha P45 is weighted. It loses some of its excellence of touch sensibility for its weighted keys, though. Casio Privia PX-160BK 88-Key Full-Size Digital Piano (Includes power supply.) Summary of features: 88 keys, built-in speakers, with the option to output to larger speakers, duet mode, split and layering capability, USB port, 18 built intones. Pros Full size (88 keys)Option to layer voices5 high-quality grand piano voicesCons Mediocre sustain pedalDelay with rapid repetition of the same keyNoisy keysFor a digital piano for a beginner, this digital piano checks all the boxes. It’s full size, produces fairly good sound, comes with a variety of voices and some options to split and layer the voices as well as utilize a duet mode. It also has a USB that makes it MIDI compatible and has its own built-in sound system. If you want to know more about this, then I will suggest you check out this link Best piano review.
